Understanding cancer

Written by Sophie Green · Published Jun 5, 2018

To reserve any of the following books for parents/carers and children dealing with cancer to your local library, click on the links to reserve them from our online catalogue, visit any of our libraries, or contact us on 01473 351249 or help@suffolklibraries.co.uk

You can sign up for a library card online for free. You can sign your child up for a library card at any age.

32C, That‚Äôs Me, by Chris Higgins

‚ÄúJess has it all - gorgeous boyfriend, the lead in the school play and Ali, her dependable best friend. Then her mum is diagnosed with breast cancer and Jess‚Äôs world is turned upside down. No-one understands what she‚Äôs going through. Jess soon realises that maybe having it all isn‚Äôt what really matters.‚Äù

What‚Äôs Up with Richard? MediKidz explain leukaemia, What‚Äôs Up with Lyndon? MediKidz explain osteosarcoma, What‚Äôs Up with Tiffany‚Äôs Dad? MediKidz explain melanoma, What‚Äôs Up with Rachel? MediKidz explain brain tumours and What‚Äôs Up with Bridget‚Äôs Mum? MediKidz explain breast cancer, by Kim Chilman-Blair & John Taddeo

The MediKidz comic novel series helps children learn about health and disease in an exciting, non-threatening way, blending fun with fact.

What You Need to Know about Cancer, by Christopher Forest

‚ÄúCancer can be a scary word. But the more you know about the causes, symptoms, and treatment of cancer, the better equipped you are to understand this disease. Clear, concise information breaks down the disease, the experience of having it, or relating to someone who has cancer.‚Äù

The Best Medicine, by Christine Hamill

‚ÄúPhilip is 12 years old and life is pretty good. He gets on with his mum and gets by pretty well at school - in spite of girl problems, teacher problems, bully problems and - er - poetry problems. Philip‚Äôs happy-go-lucky life is disrupted when his mother gets breast cancer. Bad enough that your mother is seriously ill - but could she not have developed a less embarrassing kind of cancer - toe cancer, maybe, or ear cancer?

‚ÄúPhilip‚Äôs attempt to cope with his situation are both hilarious and touching. Through it all, he‚Äôs writing letters to his hero, the comedian Harry Hill, looking for advice. Harry Hill remains stonily silent, and Philip has to get by without his advice. In the end, though, Harry Hill comes up trumps, Philip gets to do a comedy routine with him, and Philip‚Äôs mum and her cancer-mates get to have a good time too.‚Äù

The Honest Truth, by Dan Gemeinhart

‚ÄúMark has been in and out of hospital his whole life - and he‚Äôs fed up. So when his cancer returns, he decides he‚Äôs had enough. Running away with his dog Beau, he sets out to climb a mountain - and it‚Äôs only when he‚Äôs left everything behind that Mark realises he has everything to live for.‚Äù

The Famous Hat, by Kate Gaynor & Ruth Keating

‚ÄúThis book has been designed to help children with leukaemia (or other forms of cancer) to prepare for treatment, namely chemotherapy, and a stay in hospital.‚Äù

I‚Äôm a Superhero, by Daxton Wilde

‚ÄúWritten by four-year-old Daxton Wilde with the help of his mother while he was undergoing chemotherapy and radiation treatments for a brain tumour, the book places Wilde as the central character, a superhero, fighting ‚Äúa bad guy named Cancer‚Äù with the help of ‚ÄúCaptain Chemo.‚Äù‚Äù

I Know Someone with Cancer, by Sue Barraclough

‚ÄúThis series presents common behavioural and physiological health issues in a simple and inclusive way. It demystifies common health issues and also helps afflicted children feel as though they aren‚Äôt alone.‚Äù

The Fault in our Stars, by John Green

‚ÄúDespite the tumour-shrinking medical miracle that has bought her a few years, Hazel has never been anything but terminal, her final chapter inscribed upon diagnosis. But when a gorgeous plot twist named Augustus Waters suddenly appears at Cancer Kid Support Group, Hazel‚Äôs story is about to be completely rewritten.‚Äù

Sophie Green

I work for the Suffolk Libraries stock team. I also write children‚Äôs fiction, short stories and comedy. Visit my website.
